learnings.summary: Correction: The conversation began with troubleshooting PowerShell syntax issues when testing the Anthropic API
learnings.details:
The conversation began with troubleshooting PowerShell syntax issues when testing the Anthropic API connection, where curl commands with Unix syntax failed in Windows PowerShell. Time zone handling between different AI platforms creates comparison issues - when Jan's timestamps use UTC and n8n operates in AEST, time-based filtering fails because `$now. ---

**User:** Hey Claude, I'm trying to set up my Anthropic API for my AI Automation Ecosystem and ran into a problem when I ran the test snippet in Powershell:
PS C:\Users\carlo> curl https://api
learnings.evidence: The conversation began with troubleshooting PowerShell syntax issues when testing the Anthropic API connection, where curl commands with Unix syntax failed in Windows PowerShell

The more reliable approach is duplicate detection using unique page names rather than timestamp comparisons. com/v1/messages" -Method Post -Headers $headers -Body $body
```

## Option 2: Use actual curl (if installed)

If you have actual `curl` installed (not the PowerShell alias), you can use it by specifying the full path or using `curl. com/v1/messages" -Method Post -Headers $headers -Body $body
```

The key change is:
- `model = "claude-sonnet-4-20250514"` instead of `"claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022"`

This should resolve the "not_found_error" and give you a successful API response
learnings.evidence: The more reliable approach is duplicate detection using unique page names rather than timestamp comparisons

```

**For Jan's Research Format:**
Jan can include coded references in her structured outputs:
```
Priority: h (High)
System Component: aae (AAE Integration)
Assigned To: claude (Claude)
```

This approach gives you:
- Clean text fields that n8n can populate
- Standardized values that match your original select options
- Easy expansion as you add more AI agents or categories
- Human-readable codes that Jan can use in her research outputs

The codes get translated to full values automatically, maintaining consistency across your automation system
```

**For Jan's Research Format:**
Jan can include coded references in her structured outputs:
```
Priority: h (High)
System Component: aae (AAE Integration)
Assigned To: claude (Claude)
```

This approach gives you:
- Clean text fields that n8n can populate
- Standardized values that match your original select options
- Easy expansion as you add more AI agents or categories
- Human-readable codes that Jan can use in her research outputs

The codes get translated to full values automatically, maintaining consistency across your automation system

learnings.summary: Correction: Based on your earlier experience with the date formatting issue where the uppercase version didn't w
learnings.details:
Based on your earlier experience with the date formatting issue where the uppercase version didn't work, the lowercase format is more reliable in n8n expressions. **Configure it to log**: "Skipped processing - page older than 30 minutes"

This ensures:
- **True branch**: Processes recent Jan research pages through your Code → Notion automation
- **False branch**: Logs that older pages were detected but skipped (prevents silent failures)

The False branch handling is especially important for debugging. Without it, you won't know if your workflow is:
- Not finding any Jan research pages at all
- Finding pages but skipping them due to age filtering
- Having other issues

Adding the False branch gives you visibility into what the automation is doing when it runs every 15 minutes, making troubleshooting much easier when the system is fully operational
learnings.evidence: Based on your earlier experience with the date formatting issue where the uppercase version didn't work, the lowercase format is more reliable in n8n expressions

learnings.details:
**In the Set node, configure:**
   - **Operation**: "Set"
   - **Name**: "log_message" 
   - **Value**: "Skipped processing - page older than 30 minutes"

**Alternative approach - "No Operation" node:**
1. This simply terminates the workflow gracefully without processing

The Set node approach is better because it creates a data output you can reference later for debugging, while No Operation just stops the workflow silently
learnings.evidence:

   - **Name**: "log_message" 
   - **Value**: "Skipped processing - page older than 30 minutes"

learnings.summary: Correction: **User:** I got Jan to change from UTC to AEST but the IF node still didn't like it! Can the name be
learnings.details:
**User:** I got Jan to change from UTC to AEST but the IF node still didn't like it! Can the name be identified as unique in that IF node rather than complicating this with timestamps? ie after creating the database page we leave the page Jan created until I manually delete it so a new node could be added to get the workflow to include Search Notion for the page name found in the previous Search Notion node to ignore duplicates or something like that? Also, I don't know if I added the Set node to the right IF node because I just realised there are 2 of them! I ran the workflow again after moving the Edit Fields after the first and ti still sent us on the false path

**Claude:**  You're right - using unique page names for duplicate detection is much simpler than fighting timezone issues. Your current workflow has redundant components that will cause processing issues. **What you currently have:**
- Schedule Trigger → Search a page → IF (time filter) → Search a page1 → IF1 → Edit Fields → Code → Create database page

**What you actually need:**
- Schedule Trigger → Search a page → Code → Search for duplicates → IF (duplicate check) → Create database page

**Issues with your current setup:**
1

Also, I don't know if I added the Set node to the right IF node because I just realised there are 2 of them! I ran the workflow again after moving the Edit Fields after the first and ti still sent us on the false path

**Claude:**  You're right - using unique page names for duplicate detection is much simpler than fighting timezone issues

learnings.details:
The timestamp approach is unnecessarily complex when we can just check if a page with that exact name already exists in your Automation & Maintenance Schedule database. **Revised approach:**

1. **User:** Somehow I've got more nodes than you're describing!

**Claude:**  You've created extra nodes that aren't needed for the duplicate checking approach
